column1: Several stories circulate among Cocoa old timers as to how the town got its name. One story says that the mail used to come by river boat and was placed in an empty tin box labeled Baker's Cocoa. The box was nailed to a piling in the river next to downtown. Additionally

column16: the Cocoa Expo Sports Center (Cocoa Stadium) was built for the Colt 45s spring baseball training and Grapefruit League games. The team later became the Houston Astros. In the early 1980s

column1: Cocoa is located at 28°22′10″N 80°44′38″W.According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 15.4 square miles (39.9 km2). 13.3 square miles (34.5 km2) of it is land and 2.1 square miles (5.4 km2) of it (13.46%) is water. Cocoa is home to the highest point in Brevard County
column3: listed by the USGS as being 83 feet (25 m) above sea level at its apex.

column1: The Cocoa Bird Count has annually counted species of birds in or near Cocoa since 1950. In 2010
column2: it counted 150 species. There was an annual "Christmas Bird Count" before this
column3: starting in 1900.

column1: Cocoa first approved the Council-Manager form of government in 1959
column2: and subsequent changes to the state statutes mirrored the City of Cocoa's Council-Manager Plan. The City Council serves as the Board of Directors for the City
column3: with the Mayor as Chairman. The City Manager serves as the Chief Executive. The City Council for the City of Cocoa is made up of five members; the Mayor is elected at large and the four council members are elected by each of their districts.

column1: The historic downtown area is called Cocoa Village along Florida Avenue and Stone Street. It has shops and restaurants
column2: and is surrounded by historic buildings and the Cocoa Riverfront Park. The Florida Historical Society is headquartered in the historic Cocoa Post Office
column3: originally built in 1939 by the Works Progress Administration. The area was revitalized by funding for public infrastructure through the Cocoa Redevelopment Agency

column1: Tourism is high in the downtown historic business district. Cruise passenger tourists come from Port Canaveral on excursions or day trips. In addition
column2: tourists are attracted to the historic sites and local attractions such as the Brevard Museum of History & Natural Science
column3: the Eastern Florida State College Planetarium and Observatory
column9: and Riverfront Park. Historic Cocoa Village has shopping and two Golden Spoon award-winning restaurants
column10: and boutiques. The city sponsors more than 50 special events each year.

column1: The Florida East Coast Railway runs through Cocoa. A planned Virgin Trains USA higher speed rail expansion is designed to connect Orlando to Miami making a turn in Cocoa (designated the "Cocoa Curve").
Space Coast Area Transit operates a public bus service in Cocoa and vicinity.

column2: Cocoa has supplied the communities of central Brevard County with potable water.  Cocoa made major investments in the water supply and treatment facilities needed to produce a sub-regional water system.
Cocoa provided an average of 23

column18: Kennedy Space Center and Port Canaveral.

column1: Cocoa's water system includes the wellfield and raw water collection system
column2: Wewahootee Water Treatment Plant
column3: transmission mains
column4: and the Dyal Water Treatment Plant (WTP).  Cocoa's drinking water sources include the Floridian Aquifer
column7: and Aquifer Storage and Recovery (ASR) wells.  All of these facilities are located in east Orange County.  A distribution system and storage pumping facilities are located in Brevard County.

column1: The Dyal WTP processes about nine billion gallons per year
column2: with peak flows reaching 38 million gallons per day (mgd) during the summer.  Daily flows average 25 mgd.  The Dyal WTP is unusual for Central Florida because it is capable of treating both ground and surface water.
